EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A medium to large deciduous shade tree with a rounded crown. Densely branched, typically 40-60 feet tall (max 90 feet). Tends to be wider than tall when growing in an open area.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: exudes milky sap when petiole is broken
some cultivars have dark red leaves

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Small yellow flowers with five petals. Buds are large and green to maroon. Blooms in April.

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Sugar maple (Acer saccharum) has clear sap, thick, irregular plated bark, seed wings at a 120 degree angle and seeds that are thick in cross section
Norway Maple has white sap, regularly grooved bark, a 180 degree angle to its seed wings, and seeds that are thin in cross-section.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: The dense shade produced by Norway Maple inhibits the growth of other vegetation under its canopy. The fact that seeds are wind dispersed allows them to spread far from the parent plant.

On Nantucket, fruits are observed dropping from the trees in mid-June, and seem small, suggesting they may not be developing fully. Seeds do germinate but plants don't persist. Most adults are from known plantings.

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A medium to large deciduous tree, ranging from 40 to 60 feet tall. Has a dense and compact crown, with spreading, upright branches.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Yellowish green with five petals. Blooms in May.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: green maturing to brown or tan

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Norway Maple (Acer platanoides) has thin, entire leaves, an erect umbellate growth habit, and bark that is regularly grooved.
Red Maple (Acer rubrum) has thin toothed, entire leaves, an umbellate growth habit, and smooth or ridged bark with no flaking.
Sugar Maple (Acer saccharum) has thin, entire leaves, a hanging umbellate growth habit, and ridged bark in strips with no flaking.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: The large buds of this tree remain green throughout the winter. Can be distinguished from Norway Maple by the lack of milky white sap when leaf petioles are broken.
In contrast to Norway Maple, this species seems to thrive in salty conditions.

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An herbaceous perennial, 1-3 feet tall. Stem is unbranched or stiffly branched at the top.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: soft, matted wool or short hairs, or hairless
lower leaves lanceolate to oblanceolate, long petioles
upper leaves lanceolate to linear, sessile

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Many small five-petaled flowers in yellow, white, or pink. Arranged in flat-topped terminal corymbs.

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds are carried short distances by wind

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Queen Anne's lace (Daucus carota) has finely divided leaves that are true green, not hairy, with distinct spaces between leaf divisions. Yarrow leaves are densely feather-shaped and gray-green, appear felted, and are very fragrant.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: The flat topped inflorescences resembles those of Queen Anne's Lace, whose inflorescences can be distinguished by the presence of a dark central spot.

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A low-growing, herbaceous perennial. Stem erect, branched, 16-40 inches tall. A dense ground cover.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: upper leaves smaller, with short petioles

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Small, white five-petaled flowers. Arranged in dense umbels 2 to 5 inches wide. Blooms from July to August.

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Golden Alexander (Zizia aurea) has similar leaves, but a loose yellow inflorescence.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Seen as a variegated form (Variegated Bishop's Goutweed) in landscapes and gardens. With its low creeping nature, Goutweed can completely take over the forest understories, eliminating native plants.
Planted in Maria Mitchell's garden, and likely elsewhere, but has not yet been reported outside of cultivation on Nantucket.

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A medium, deciduous shade tree with a spreading and open shape. Typically 40-60 feet tall and shaped wide. Fast growing.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Inconspicuous yellow panicles of five-petaled flowers. Dioecious
male flowers emit acrid odor. Blooms from early to mid June.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: yellow to red maturing to brown

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds are carried primarily by wind

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Sumacs (Rhus typhina, R. glabra, R. copallina): Sumacs have leaves with toothed margins, and the fruits are tight clusters of small red berries.
Black walnut (Juglans nigra) and Butternut (J. cinerea): Pinnately compound leaves and hard-coated green fruits or nuts
Tree-of-heaven leaves have smooth margins with slightly lobed bases. The fruits are papery-winged samaras.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Tree of Heaven can be found growing in any disturbed areas. It produces lots (350,000) of seeds and has a rapid growth rate. The toxins which are produced within the leaves and bark inhibit growth around the tree as toxins accumulate in the soil.
On Nantucket, there are four known populations of this species. At least two are spreading to natural areas, the largest one being on Mill Hill.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: bark gray, smooth, light vertical streaks

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: 5 leaflets attached to a single leaf stalk

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Fragrant purple or white three-petaled flowers in axillary racemes. Blooms from April to May.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: white core with tiny black seeds arranged in irregular rows

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: birds may disperse fruits, if fruits are present
vegetatively by rooting of stem nodes

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Rapid growth once established, spreads by vegetative and seed dispersal. Five-leaf Akebia can grow as a dense groundcover or smother trees and shrubs as it grows over them. Introduction and spread of Akebia is largely due to inadvertent human activities. Planting as a ornamental vine is common sources of garden escapes. This vine takes about 5 years to mature into a fruit bearing plant, though fruits and flowers are relatively uncommon.
On Nantucket, this species is known from a single site where it has been since the early 1990s. Plants have spread to the other side of the street , perhaps via mowing.

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Alliaria officinalis, Erysimum alliaria, Sisymbrium alliaria

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A highly fragrant, herbaceous biennial. In the first year, growth is low (3-7 inches) as a non-flowering basal rosette. In the second year flowering stems reach 3.3 feet tall.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: basal rosette remains green throughout winter
basal leaves 2.4-4 inches long and wide
stem leaves 1.2-3.1 inches long and wide, decrease in size up the stem

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Small, cruciform white flowers (.25 inches wide) with four petals. Blooms from April to May.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: pods or siliques (1-2.4 inches long and 0.8 inch wide)
green drying to a brittle brown
by June the plant dies back and the fruits persist

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds stick to clothing, shoes, and wildlife, and are also passively dispersed close to the parent plant

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Garlic mustard can rapidly overtake an area by emerging in early spring before other vegetation and through prolific seed production. Roots contain phytotoxins which may inhibit the growth of other plants.

Items.name: Degree of invasiveness on Nantucket
Items.Item: Do not list at this time

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Wild onion, Field garlic, Crow garlic

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: asexually by bulbils that form in place of fruits in the flower head

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: More information about the invasiveness of this species elsewhere is required to determine whether it might be a potential threat.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: Plant parts all emit a strong garlic odor.

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A perennial vine that can reach 10-20 feet high. Vines bear tendrils.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Green cymes densely covered with five-petaled flowers. Blooms from July to August.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: whitish, lilac, green ripen to sky blue

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Grown as a landscape plant this vine creates dense mats, and can over-compete with natives for water and nutrients. The fact that it is relatively insect and disease resistant allows this vine to take over an area.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: fruit yellow, lilac, and green ripen to blue

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Berberis thunbergii var. atropurpurea, B. sinensis, B. japonica

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A dense, woody shrub, fountain or dome shaped. Typically 3-6 feet tall.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: green, red, copper or variegated leaves

EFGLists.name: THE STEM
EFGLists.EFGList: single thorns or with 2 small thorns

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Yellow, .25 inches wide, six-petaled flowers. Flowers are single or in dangling umbel, held in leaf axils. Blooms in May.

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: birds (turkey and grouse) and small mammals
branches can root if they make contact with the soil

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Common barberry (Berberis vulgaris): Leaves have toothed margins, flowers hang in a long cluster under leaves
Berberis × ottawensis (hybrid of B. thunbergii and B. vulgaris): Intermediate characters from both parents, can be difficult to distinguish.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Japanese barberry is typically grown for its showy fruits and its fall leaf color. Reproduction is mainly through seed which are spread by birds. Japanese and Common Barberry naturalize easily and should not be planted in landscapes, due to its ability to out compete native species.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: green, red, copper or variegated leaves

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A deciduous, woody perennial. Grows as a vine or sometimes as a trailing shrub.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Small (.07 to .15 inches long, .1 to .2 inches wide) greenish five-petaled flowers held in leaf axils. Blooms from May to early June.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: green maturing to yellow, orange then tan

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: also reproduces vegetatively by root suckers

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: American bittersweet (Celastrus scandens): A native species that looks similar, but develops fruits only at the ends of stems, not in leaf axils as with Oriental bittersweet. Contrast between arils and ovary walls is not as strong as with Oriental bittersweet.
There is a hybrid between C. scandens and C. orbiculatus that can be difficult to distinguish.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Asiatic bittersweet is a threat to native vegetation due to its rapid growth rate, the ability to send up shoots from roots (root suckering), and high reproductive rates allows for dense and quick growth. This climbing vine shades out native vegetation and can kill large trees by constricting or girdling stems or by adding weight to limbs causing them to break. Oriental or Asiatic Bittersweet is often confused with native American Bittersweet (C. scandens), which flowers at the tips rather than in the leaf axils. Improper disposal after use in floral arrangements contributes to the spread of Asiatic Bittersweet.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: yellow fruits open to reveal red, fleshy arils

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Centaurea biebersteinii, C. maculosa, Acosta maculosa

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A biennial or short-lived perennial, 1-3 feet tall, with a stout taproot. Slightly pubescent, with one or more branched upright stems.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Thistle-like flowering heads with many petals. The ray flowers are pinkish purple, seldom cream colored. The involucral bracts are stiff and tipped with a dark, comb-like fringe. Blooms from June to October.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: tipped with a tuft of persistent bristles

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: can resprout from lateral root buds or from crown of leaves, especially following attempts at removal

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Russian knapweed (Centaurea repens), Cornflower (C. cyanus), Diffuse knapweed (C. diffusa), Black knapweed (C. nigra), and Brown knapweed (C. jacea) all have similar inflorescences
Other knapweeds lack the black-tipped flower bracts that are characteristic of this species.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Spotted knapweed can invade and seriously effect the biodiversity of an area, by choking out native vegetation. Erosion occurs due to its inability to hold the soil. Hand-pulling, cutting or mowing over several years may successfully eliminate Spotted Knapweed. ; On Nantucket, this species has been seen growing along the Madaket bike path heading west

Items.name: Degree of invasiveness on Nantucket
Items.Item: Do not list at this time

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An herbaceous biennial, 1-2 feet tall. Stems are branched.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: short, soft hairs along veins on underside of leaves

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Yellow, four-petaled flowers with many stamens. Flowers are arranged in small umbels and are held in leaf axils. Blooms from May to June.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: This species can be numerous in disturbed sites and outcompete native plants.
On Nantucket, this species is fairly prevalent, mostly on roadsides and wooded edges.

Items.name: Degree of invasiveness on Nantucket
Items.Item: Do not list at this time

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Succory, Blue sailors, Blue daisy, Coffee-weed, Bunk

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An unbranched, herbaceous perennial, 2-4 feet tall, with leaves in a basal rosette.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Stalkless flowers with blue, violet, sometimes white, or rarely pink, with many petals. Petal tips are square and fringed. Flowers close during mid-day.

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: The leaves of Dandelion (Taraxacum officinale) strongly resembles the basal rosette of Chicory, but Dandelion leaves generally have oppositely arranged toothed lobes that point backwards, while Chicory has lobes that generally alternate and point in variable directions. Chicory has coarser leaf hairs and rougher textured leaves than Dandelion.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: The ground-up roots of this species are still used today as a coffee substitute.
On Nantucket, this is a common roadside weed.

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Cirsium incanum, C. setosum, Carduus arvensis, Breea arvensis, B. incana, Serratula arvensis

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: Leaf lobes are tipped with needle-like thorns.

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Can be confused with other thistle species.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: The places where it is found on Nantucket are not pristine, but having been disturbed in the past, are now natural.

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Spear thistle, Common thistle, Fuller's thistle
Cirsium lanceolatum, Carduus lanceolatus, Carduus vulgaris

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An upright, biennial plant with a taproot, reaching 2-6 feet tall.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Reddish purple flowers with large heads and many petals. Flowers are solitary or in groups of two or three. Bracts have rigid, yellow-tipped spines on them.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: yellowish brown, black or purple streaks
narrow yellow band at the top
topped with a white pappus (plume-like hairs) up to 1 inch long

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Resembles Canada thistle (Cirsium arvense) which has creeping roots, smaller flowers, weak prickles, and lacks the thorny stems. There are many native Cirsium species which may resemble Bull thistle. Many of the natives don't have leaves that clasp the stem all the way from node to node, their leaf surfaces are hairy above and below, and are blue-green or gray in color.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: This species can cause agricultural losses by restricting livestock grazing, and is also very aggressive in disturbed areas.

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Clematis dioscoreifolia, C. maximowicziana, C. paniculata

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A scrambling vine with thin stems

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: White, fragrant, four-petaled flowers on multi-stemmed clusters from leaf axils.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: typically 1-4 fruits per stalk, a red, flat achene topped with a showy, feathery "flag"

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Widespread on Nantucket, both in gardens and in the wild

Items.name: Degree of invasiveness on Nantucket
Items.Item: Do not list at this time

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Flowers have two paired blue upper petals, and one lower white petal that is quite small and therefore inconspicuous. As the common name suggests, these flowers fade by the end of the day on which they open.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: On Nantucket, this species is often found around pond shores. Further investigation is required to determine whether it might pose a threat to pond shore plants.

Items.name: Degree of invasiveness on Nantucket
Items.Item: Do not list at this time

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Lance-leaf tickseed, Long-stalk Tickseed, Sand coreopsis, Sand tickseed

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An herbaceous perennial, 2-3 feet tall. Plants have a clumplike habit, with erect flower stems.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: mostly on lower half of stem

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Eight yellow ray flowers with four deep lobes at the tips. Scape-like flower stalks.

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: also through dumping of garden waste and contaminated soil

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Large flowered coreopsis (Coreopsis graniflora) is very similar but is taller (about 3 feet) and has leaves the entire length of the stem.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: While this species is native to central and southeastern United States, it is not native to the New England area. Due to its dense clumping habit and prolific self-seeding it can crowd out native plants and reduce the success rate of native seed germination. It is commonly planted in yards and gardens, but care should be taken as the plant easily naturalizes as an invasive self-seeder. The wind and water spread seeds are the primary cause for dispersal of this plant, but contaminated garden soil and garden waste dumping additionally contribute to its wide range establishment.
On Nantucket, this species is still heavily planted, and is escaping from cultivation. Seems to persist in grasslands but not visibly outcompeting the native flora.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Pink and white bicolored, bilaterally symmetrical pea-like flowers with five petals. Arranged in circular clusters. Blooms from June to August.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: a green pod, much like typical legumes

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds are dispersed short distances by the plant when pods open
sometimes intentionally planted to combat soil erosion

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Many of the vetches (Vicia spp.) resemble Crown vetch, which can be distinguished by its lack of a terminal tendril and flowers that are arranged in a circular umbel, rather than the long racemes or small clusters of other vetches.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Planted as an agricultural cover crop and for erosion control along roadsides and steep banks. Crown-vetch can reproduce prolifically and crowd out native species within sunny areas, it is intolerant of deep shade.

On Nantucket, a well-established population with significant root structure and nearby seedlings was removed from a dirt road and roadside in the Sesachacha Heathlands (within one of Nantucket's Biodiversity Plots) in 2006. This species occurs on other parts of the island in native vegetation, typically near traveled places such as paths, but also several yards off roadside in natural areas. It sas repeatedly dispersed over spatial gaps.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: round inflorescence made up of dozens of pea-like flowers

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An herbaceous, perennial vine growing up to 6.5 feet long. Stems are unbranched but can twine around each other to form thick spirals.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Dark purple to almost black five-petaled flowers in clusters of six to ten. The corolla is five-lobed, with triangle shaped, fleshy petals. Petals are slightly toothed, with short, straight, white hairs on the upper surface, joined together by a connective membrane. Blooms from June to September.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds flat, brown, ovoid, membranous wing on margin
tuft of white hairs at one end

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds dispersed primarily by wind, sometimes by water

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Pale swallow-wort (Cynanchum rossicum) has pale yellow-purple to reddish corolla lobes and smooth, hairless corolla lobes that are twice as long as wide. Black swallow-wort (Cynanchum louiseae) has dark purple, deltoid shaped corolla lobes with short white hairs.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Rapid growth and wind dispersed seeds allow Black Swallow-wort to outgrow and crowd native vegetation.
This species is a relatively recent arrival on Nantucket. Vines are often found wrapped around other invasive species. Spreading from Sconset.

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A short perennial shrub, no more than 6.5 feet tall, with upright branches.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Most commonly bright yellow, with some cultivars pale yellow, pink, or red. Flowers are located in upper axils, either solitary or in pairs, in long terminal racemes. Blooms in late May or June.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds are small, multicolored (green, brown, dark brown, rust) and obovate to round

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds are ejected from the plant when pods open

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Many cultivated varieties are available with a wide range of flower colors.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Scotch broom is planted for ornamental purposes and for dune stabilizing.
On Nantucket, there is one known large population at Madawi Creek, else plants are typically found in small groups.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: dark green upper, light green below

Items.name: Degree of invasiveness on Nantucket
Items.Item: Do not list at this time

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A stout, branched annual with a sprawling habit, 2-5 feet tall.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Large, white, trumpet-shaped, solitary flowers. Corollas are up to 6 inches long, with five points and a purple tinge on the margins. Flowers are short stalked and held in leaf axils. They open after dark and close by mid-morning.

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds are moved around by clothing, shoes, in hay and farm equipment

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Common cocklebur (Xanthium strumarium) seedlings lack the distinct odor, prominent teeth and smooth leaves of jimsonweed.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: All parts of this plant are poisonous, to humans and livestock. Naturalizes and becomes weedy.

Items.name: Degree of invasiveness on Nantucket
Items.Item: Do not list at this time

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An herbaceous biennial with a taproot, 1-3 feet tall.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: alternate, compound, linear or lanceolate divisions
rough hairs on top and bottom

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: White five-petaled flowers arranged in dense umbels up to 4 inches across. The stems of the outer flowers are shorter than those of the inner flowers.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: some have spines with oil tubes

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: barbed seeds are dispersed by animals, humans and wind

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: The white topped umbels of Queen Anne's Lace resemble those of the white-flowered form of Yarrow (Achilliea millefolium).
Mayweed chamomile (Anthemis cotula) has erect, flowering stems that are leafy.
Poison-hemlock (Conium maculatum) is also similar but has smooth, purple spotted stems that are rigid.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: This species can compete with native plants for resources. It has an advantage in severely disturbed habitats because it grows taller and matures faster than many native plants.
On Nantucket, this species is found in some natural areas.

Items.name: Degree of invasiveness on Nantucket
Items.Item: Do not list at this time

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A shrub or small tree, growing up to 35 feet tall.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: silver scales on top and bottom of leaf

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Fragrant four-petaled flowers are silvery outside and deep yellow within. One to three flowers grow from each leaf axil. Blooms from May to June.

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: birds and small mammals spread the seeds

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Russian Olive (E. angustifolia) and Autumn Olive (E. umbellata) look very similar, even to the trained eye.

Russian Olive has linear, narrow leaves, with the upper leaf surface sparsely silver and lower surface densely silver. Autumn Olive has an elliptical shape with an upper leaf surface that is rarely silver and a lower surface sparsely silver with brown scales. Autumn Olive flowers are cream to pale yellow, and its fruits are juicy and red or sometimes orange to gold. Russian Olive flowers are brighter yellow and its fruits are larger, dry and yellow with silvery scales.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: The nitrogen fixing abilities can effect native species which are adapted to infertile soils. Due to its heavy fruiting, rapid growth, tolerance of poor soils, and seed dispersal by birds, these shrubs can out-compete native species.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: silver scales top and bottom of leaf

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A deciduous shrub reaching 12 to 20 feet tall.

EFGLists.name: THE STEM
EFGLists.EFGList: young branches silvery and scaly maturing to darker brown

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Small, tubular, light yellow flowers with four petals. They are extremely fragrant. Blooms from May to June.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: a golden-fruited cultivar is also naturalized

EFGLists.name: THE HABITAT
EFGLists.EFGList: tolerates poor soils due to its nitrogen-fixing root nodules

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: birds and small mammals spread the seeds

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Russian Olive (E. angustifolia) and Autumn Olive (E. umbellata) look very similar, even to the trained eye.

Russian Olive has linear, narrow leaves, with the upper leaf surface sparsely silver and lower surface densely silver. Autumn Olive has an elliptical shape with an upper leaf surface that is rarely silver and a lower surface sparsely silver with brown scales. Autumn Olive flowers are cream to pale yellow, and its fruits are juicy and red or sometimes orange to gold. Russian Olive flowers are brighter yellow and its fruits are larger, dry and yellow with silvery scales.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: The nitrogen fixing abilities can effect native species which are adapted to infertile soils. Due to its heavy fruiting, rapid growth, tolerance of poor soils, and seed dispersal by birds, these shrubs can out-compete native species.

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An herbaceous perennial that spreads through rhizomes.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Rose colored four-petaled flowers that grow from leaf axils. Petal bases are pubescent.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: 2-3 inches long, skinny capsules, green drying to brown
split open into four pieces to reveal oblong, flat seeds attached to tufts of long, white hairs

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: wind-dispersed seeds are a secondary means of spread

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: The leaves of E. angustifolium are longer and hairless.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Hairy Willow Herb can out crowd native plants in wetland areas.
On Nantucket, this species is restricted to wetlands. It is known in only four or five locations, but at those locations it exists as a monoculture.

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Filaree, Redstem filaree, Common storksbill, Heronbill, Alfilaria, Pin-weed, Pin-grass

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An erect winter annual or biennial, 6-8 inches tall.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Magenta to purple five-petaled flowers growing in umbels. Sepals are light-green striped. Flowers are bristle tipped with silky hairs.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: spirally coiled at maturity in dry conditions

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds are dispersed through wind, water and through contaminated hay, manure and farm machinery

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Whitestem filaree (Erodium moschatum) and Carolina geranium (Geranium carolinianum) both resemble stork's bill. Whitestem filaree has broader and longer compound leaves with shallow cut leaflet. Carolina geranium has rounded and palmately veined leaves and outwardly coiled beaks at maturity.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Stork's bill is considered invasive because of its ability to crowd out native plants and outcompete agricultural crops.
On Nantucket, there was a massive population explosion of this species in 2006, mostly on disturbed soils.

EFGLists.name: Synonyms
EFGLists.EFGList: Winged euonymus, Winged burning bush, Winged wahoo, Winged spindle-tree

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: A branching, deciduous shrub with an erect habit. Compact, 6-9 feet tall.

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Creamy white to green flowers with four petals. Flowers are .25 to .33 inches wide. They grow in clusters borne from the leaf axils.

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: seeds also drop underneath the plant

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Burning bush is the only local species with winged stems.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Flowers are relatively inconspicuous. Burning Bush or Winged Euonymus can take over open woodland habitats creating a monoculture as it pushes out native shrubs. Due to its matted, dense root system, and dense shade, few other plants can succeed beneath Burning bush.
Some younger plants or cultivated varieties may lack the winged stems.
On Nantucket, two individuals are known in the wild.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: winged stems (some cultivars may lack wings)

EFGLists.name: THE PLANT
EFGLists.EFGList: An herbaceous to semi-woody perennial, 6-12 inches tall.

EFGLists.name: THE LEAVES
EFGLists.EFGList: uppermost leaves opposite or whorled giving rise to terminal inflorescence

EFGLists.name: THE STEM
EFGLists.EFGList: when broken release white milky latex

EFGLists.name: THE FLOWERS
EFGLists.EFGList: Yellow-green complex flowers that lack true sepals or petals. Two cordate bracts that resemble petals begin yellow-green and mature into a purplish red color. Arranged in broad terminal umbels, with many male flowers clustered around one female flower which is enclosed by an involucre with 4 horned glands which is yellow-green and matures to orange brown. Blooms from May to August.

EFGLists.name: THE FRUITS
EFGLists.EFGList: green to shades of red, orange and yellow

EFGLists.name: THE HABITAT
EFGLists.EFGList: old fields, cemeteries, grasslands, roadsides, waste places

EFGLists.name: DISPERSAL METHODS
EFGLists.EFGList: also reproduces vegetatively by lateral root buds

EFGLists.name: SIMILAR SPECIES
EFGLists.EFGList: Leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula) is another invasive that resembles Cypress spurge, but is taller, more robust, and has wider leaves. Cypress spurge (E. cyparissias) has very thin, linear leaves and smaller flower bracts.

EFGLists.name: NOTES
EFGLists.EFGList: Cypress spurge is often very numerous in disturbed areas due to its ability to reproduce vegetatively. Humans can be sensitive to the milky-white latex within the plant and it is deemed an agricultural pest as it is toxic to horses and cattle.

EFGLists.name: KEY ID FEATURES
EFGLists.EFGList: stems release milky white latex when broken
